hints.content: Start by understanding what a prefix is. A prefix of a number is formed by taking the leftmost digits. For example, for the number 12345, the prefixes are 1, 12, 123, 1234, and 12345.
Remember that you need to find the longest common prefix between pairs of integers from the two arrays. This means you will need to compare each integer in arr1 with each integer in arr2.
Consider how to extract the digits of an integer. You can convert the integer to a string to easily access its digits and compare prefixes.
Think about how to iterate through both arrays. You can use nested loops to compare each element from arr1 with each element from arr2.
When comparing two integers, you need to find the common prefix. Start by converting both integers to strings and then compare their characters one by one until they differ.
Keep track of the length of the longest common prefix found during your comparisons. You can use a variable to store the maximum length encountered.
Be mindful of edge cases, such as when one of the arrays is empty or when there are no common prefixes at all. What should your function return in these cases?
Consider the performance of your solution. Given the constraints (up to 50,000 integers in each array), ensure that your approach is efficient enough to handle the worst-case scenario.
When comparing prefixes, if you find a common prefix, you can stop checking further characters once they differ. This can save time in your comparisons.
Finally, ensure that your function returns the length of the longest common prefix. You might want to return 0 if no common prefix is found after checking all pairs.

questionNotes: Common prefixes must be between elements of arr1 and arr2 only.
Return 0 if no common prefix exists.
